Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Story: My phone buzzes with a message from Mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend! Call us when you can.” I glance at the clock—Sunday evening already. I haven’t called home all week, just sent a quick text yesterday. Guilt prickles at me; I know how much my parents value hearing my voice, not just reading a line or two. But as I start to dial, another message pops up—this time from Alex: “Hey, want to do dinner tomorrow or Tuesday? Miss you.” We’ve both been busy, and finally, our schedules line up. I want to be present with him, to show him he’s a priority, not just someone I squeeze in. But if I spend tomorrow with Alex, I’ll probably be too tired to call home, and if I call my parents tonight, I’ll be distracted, thinking about plans with Alex. I feel torn, pulled between being a good daughter and a loving girlfriend, wishing I could be both at once without letting anyone down. My thumb hovers over the call button, heart heavy with the weight of choosing.
